author: Dose_of_Reality
body:
~270% gain in weed stocks (canopy, acb, aph) in 2017/early 2018.  Pulled in over 16k.  Was warned about the bubble and pulled out.  Missed out on huge gains over 2018 but was long gone by the time the crash happened.  Was very close to jumping back in, but glad I never did. 

Tried to pick the bottom and catch a falling knife with SNC.  Was down -65% (almost 4K) at one point.  Kept dollar cost averaging on the way down.  And doing just fine now.

author: TonyBeets63
body:
I mean they (aph) just finished getting DD and are starting to fill it with plants and other companies are halting and or selling off assets. 
Is apha full steam ahead into the abyss of writedowns and sell offs, like others just did OR like I said before. Are they the greatest LP of all time?

author: wolfcrossMJ
body: I donno bro to be fair this domain is pretty aware we all mostly agree aph has the best weed and its often sold out even randoms on street i talk to often are in aph its got its fair share of recognition may not be getting discounted as much as you believe it is, just doesnt have he same size as acb n weed but its got its respect... the whole my stock vs your stock has to chill a bit we move as a sector

author: cokanagan
body:
Gambled on APHA earnings instead of OGI.

OGI think this decision bit me in the APH

author: skinniks
body: They said the first full harvest would be beginning of November.  Keep in mind that there is a larger lag then one woudl expect to cure and package weed after harvest.  I think next quarter's financials will give us a better picture of how Aph 1 is producing.

author: PristineEmotion3
body: The ACB facility in Germany is making the same progress build-wise as the APH facility. You are slightly mistaken about "doesn't have cash...". They announced that they are prioritizing their existing cash responsibly and putting their dollars into projects with the most return. Since Canada has (more or less) enough supply for now, their last remaining build, Sun, is only going to be (temporarily) partially completed with full completion in the future.

author: Sectsytime
body: I know it's looked like it before but APH really looks primed to have a stellar next couple of quarters. Holding isn't the worst idea cause you'll still profit if it happens.

author: Shotgun516
body: I believe you’re right about that re: the supplier. But hey it’s a start of revenues to come for tbp which APH gets 20% of. It’s better than nothing

author: Shotgun516
body: Tbp needs to bring massive amounts of revenue now with this info. APH will get its share when they get 20% of what TBP will eventually make

author: skinniks
body:
I don't know why I find the need to always defend them except that their detractors always make the most stupid accusations.  Nothing in your post makes sense.  They also toured aurora sun and raved about it and they have toured other companies as well.  Are they ACB shills?  Tantalus shills?   They have seriously criticized LHS (especially the CFO) and Blue actually holds a position.  So are they shilling for them? 

 They've done AMAs with serious players in the sector.  They have put together industry conferences and attracted a wide variety of leading figures in the industry.  Would these people associate with the cannalysts if they were just paid Aph shills?

It's one thing to say they are fucking morons who provide no value and another to accuse them of being paid to shill for Aph.  Given that they have monetized their brand maybe weedstocks mods should do a better job of not allowing baseless libel in these threads.

body: Praying for aph to knock it out of the park

author: WVR_Phil
body:
Hindsight is 2020, to be completely fair with those gains and relate them to weedstocks, I bought my first 1000 shares of APH at $1.21, 20 months later they were worth $24.75, that's a 2050% gain in 20 months.

&#x200B;

unfortunately I sold them at $9.75 and own a shit ton of shares that I paid considderably more for now.  


I bought SHOP at $95 and sold at $128 to buy more APHA, that hurst as well, but I am still confident I will retire well off from this sector

body:
He throws enough mud that sometimes some sticks.

- He was wrong after stating the OH/CL deal had fallen apart & was over after hearing 'rumours on Bay St' 
- He was wrong after stating that CL were caught up in some illegal bribery activity with HHH in MA. 
- He was incorrect recently with the APH vape pen manufactures.

He never admits when he is incorrect, but hypes it up when he gets some right. Selective memory, rude person.

author: Raptorswon
body:
Take some time over the weekend to peruse through this thread

 [https://www.reddit.com/r/TheCannalysts/comments/ewsbbm/aphria\_inc\_ama\_february\_5th\_2020/?sort=top](https://www.reddit.com/r/TheCannalysts/comments/ewsbbm/aphria_inc_ama_february_5th_2020/?sort=top) 

The Cananlyst community is presenting APH management with some very pointed and relevant questions. High quality questions that might impact your investing habits. I can't imagine they'll respond to some of the more flammable ones, but it'll be interesting watching them try.

author: BoomerMayn

author: mcorliss3456
body: Revenue growth means nothing at this point, but cost containment and proximity to profitability is the ultimate arbiter of valuation.  If you think APH shouldn’t be $1B mkt cap, then CGC should be selling for cash value and ACB about $500MM.  Their assets mean next to nothing if they are not productive and can produce a profit.  Those two should not be selling for a premium to APH...if anything, a discount.  Cannabis is the only industry where the physics of finance are ass backwards, but as more time goes on, true equilibrium will settle in.  Forget everything from the past 2-3 years, because it was all Fantasyland any way.  Serious!

author: Shotgun516
body: It’s really a shame the way APH stock gets treated. The only Canadian cannabis company I would consider investing in based on financials alone. I’m glad they own 20% of TBP because if tbp gets in trouble, they have a good company backing them

author: skinniks
body: Yes, disagree away.  What you can't do is make baseless accusations against a company that can harm their brand.  You can say their podcasts suck, their website is crappy and their content not worth paying for.  You can say molly is an abrasive asshole or cyto is a moron or blue is a loudmouth blowhard.  But calling them paid shills for Aph is an accusation that requires proof and crosses a line.

author: argyleshu
body: What? So they have available weed to send to other LPs since those other LPs can’t grow enough (including APH), and now you’re saying that that isn’t a forever deal? They can’t sell it somewhere else? With your logic APH should have been around < 20 million revenue since if they can’t grow it we shouldn’t count it..

author: skinniks
body:
ACB has liquidity issues but they also lead in market share, cannabis revenues, and 2.0 product range and there is a viable path to profitability unlike with CGC.  There is a lot to like there (admittedly also lots of risk if they can't restructure debt or get a large cash infusion) and I'm not sure why Aph fanboys feel the need to shit on them

Note: I don't own a single share of ACB and I own quite a bit of Aph.

author: modo85
body:
> u/arauz7 was right along. While aph may be relatively undervalued compared to bloated pigs like acb and weed, it was always relative and never as a standalone company. And the cannabis sector doesnt trade in some invisible silo.

The CPO has struggled with that basic concept for years, despite many attempts at the explanation.

Aphria is a poor investment (but may be a good speculation). Canopy and Aurora being even poorer ones doesn't change that fact, and that's really the only response you ever receive around here these days when you try to have a reasonable discussion about valuations.

Aphria does not have anywhere close to 2B in assets, so these book values often touted are complete bunk.

author: InternetSlave

author: skinniks
body:
Personally I think it's less about stench than it is about execution.  

In late 2019 they had to (and will have to) sleeve 3rd party product.  That blows my mind.

Imagine If they were getting the yields they advertise and last financials they had wholesale revenue and not wholesale costs.  Even ignoring the distribution revenue dip they would have shown significant QoQ increase cannabis revenue including 45% increase in adult use.

This to me is the story.  I can't wait to see the harvest numbers next Q because if this isn't just some kind of ramp up issue and is more a systematic issue with their automation (they've already said they had to grow smaller plants than anticipated to have it play nicely with the machinery) then this is a much bigger problem.

Regarding stench - Aph has had 40% and other significant runs.  The investment money will be there if there is a reason to be.  Stench or no stench.

author: aneeta96
body:
Looks like you are correct.

Most recent info I  could find, April 2019, shows ACB at 14.1% and APH at 9.6%. 

I imagine that gap has shrunk a bit and will probably shrink more this year with APH increasing production while ACB is dealing with more debt than cash.

Still puts ACB at around $2.50 a share maybe $3 if they can manage to grow their market share this year.

Looks like the total market was $3 billion not the  $5 billion that I thought it was.
